item.description:
The museum opens at 10 a.m. and the Festival starts at 11 a.m. I may try to get there at 10 a.m. because all the exhibits look interesting. I will wear the meetup logo pinned to my backpack-purse. I plan to take the Adult Docent-Led Tour at 1 p.m. I think I won't want to stick around for the film at 4:45, but if you're interested in the film, you need to make a reservation for yourself by May 20. - Anna

Weavers, dancers, puppet masters, hieroglyphics experts and artists illuminate the Maya culture of Guatemala and Mexico. Come see the ancient arts come to life! This event is 11 a.m.-4 p.m. but I am interested in all the exhibits too.
DEMONSTRATIONS
Maya Dugouts
Boat builder Wade Smith reconstructs a large-scale, speculative model of a dugout canoe based on ancient Maya designs.

Weaving the Waterways
Using back strap or stick looms, skilled weavers of Maya descent create a traditional huipil, a blouse with water motifs.

Guatemala Maya Sawdust Carpet
Master artist Ubaldo Sanchez creates an alfombra from hand-dyed sawdust, rice, dried beans and flowers on the Atrium floor. Help make the border!

DOCENT-LED GALLERY TOURS
Fiery Pool: The Maya and the Mythic Sea
Family tour, 11:30 am | Adult tour, 1 pm

Tickets available on the day of the tour at the admissions desk

DANCE
Grupo Awal | noon and 3 pm | Atrium
Young troupe members represent the Maya culture of Guatemala through folk dances, dress and cultural traditions. At PEM, see these 20-minute dance tributes to Maiz, or corn.

PERFORMANCES
Puppet Theater | 1:15 and 4 pm | Atrium
Gustavo Boada and members of the dance troupe Grupo Awal perform the Maya creation story — El Popol Vuh — with life-size puppets.

PRESENTATION AND DEMONSTRATION
Who Shall Read Them? The Decipherment of Maya Hieroglyphics
Morse Auditorium and Art Studios
Marc Zender, an eminent scholar of Maya hieroglyps, talks about the ancient writing system and deciphering techniques. From 3:45–4:45 pm, join a beginner's workshop and make your own glyphs! For adults and teens. Reservations for both programs by May 20.

FILM
Breaking the Maya Code | 4:45–6:45 pm | Morse Auditorium
2008, 116 minutes, directed by David Lebrun
